greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of unordered divisor pairs of n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537 (terms 1..1000 from Harry J. Smith)
formula: a(p) = 1 iff p is a prime.

Combinations of d(n), the number of divisors of n (A000005), taken two at a time. If the canonical factorization of n into prime powers is Product p^e(p) then d(n) = Product (e(p) + 1). Therefore a(n) = C(d(n), 2) = d(n)*{ d(n)-1 }/2 which is a triangular number (A000217).
a(n) = Sum_{k|n, i|n, i < k} 1. - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Aug 20 2020
example: The divisors of 6 are 1, 2, 3 & 6. In unordered pairs they are {1, 2}, {1, 3}, {1, 6}, {2, 3}, {2, 6}, & {3, 6}. Since there are six pairs, a(6) = 6. Also d(6) = 4. 4*3/2 = 6.
program: (PARI) { for (n=1, 1000, a=binomial(numdiv(n), 2); write("b066446.txt", n, " ", a) ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Feb 15 2010
results.author: _Robert G. Wilson v_, Dec 28 2001
